quotes.quote: Life is like a game of cards. The hand you are dealt is determinism, the way you play it is free will.
Free will is an illusion. People always choose the perceived path of greatest pleasure.
Free will, though it makes evil possible, is also the only thing that makes possible any love or goodness or joy worth having.
And one who is just of his own free will shall not lack for happiness; and he will never come to utter ruin.

Let all the 'free-will' in the world do all it can with all its strength; it will never give rise to a single instance of ability to avoid being hardened if God does not give the Spirit, or of meriting mercy if it is left to its own strength.
If God thinks this state of war in the universe a price worth paying for free will...then we may take it it is worth paying.
The essence of spiritual life is simply to use our free will properly.
The neutral view of free will is impossible. It involves choice without desire.
Free will is to mind what chance is to matter.
Free will is not the liberty to do whatever one likes, but the power of doing whatever one sees ought to be done, even in the very face of otherwise overwhelming impulse. There lies freedom, indeed.
Morality pertains only to the sphere of man's free will - only to those actions which are open to his choice.

Man has reason, discrimination and free-will such as it is. The brute has no such thing. It is not a free agent, and knows no distinction between virtue and vice, good and evil. Man, being a free agent, knows these distinctions, and when he follows his higher nature, shows himself far superior to the brute, but when he follows his baser nature can show himself lower than the brute.
Mankind has a free will; but it is free to milk cows and to build houses, nothing more.
The greatest judgment which God himself can, in the present life, inflict upon a man is to leave him in the hand of his own boasted 'free'-will.
...free will does not mean one will, but many wills conflicting in one man. Freedom cannot be conceived simply.
You can't have it both ways. You can't have both free will and a benevolent higher power who protects you from yourself.
No one has free will until they are an adult, and by then the choices that were made for them, have already set them on a course that gives limited freedom in the choices to be made.
The question of free will is insoluble on strictly psychological grounds.
Free will is the power of choosing good and evil.
No tribe unites with another of its own free will.
One of my core beliefs is that belief itself is a choice that can be made of our own free will.
Our hands we open of our own free will, and the good flies, which we can never recall.
Think of destiny more like potentiality because of an element called - free will.
Contempt for the things people choose of their own free will is, at its heart, contempt for free will.

Free will does not enable any man to perform good works, unless he is assisted by grace; indeed, the special grace which the elect alone receive through regeneration. For I stay not to consider the extravagance of those who say that grace is offered equally and promiscuously to all
You have fettered yourself of your own free will, man - break the fetters!
It is only work that is done as freewill offering to humanity and to nature that does not bring with it any binding attachment.
